author: Nagesh Prabhu
text:
Home Minister denies Opposition charge of lathi-charge on protesters

The Karnataka government, which is facing the Opposition’s wrath for the poor handling of the protest by the farmers of Kolar and Chickballapur districts who blocked the Kempe Gowda International Airport here defying the ban, told both the Houses of the legislature on Friday that it will withdraw cases registered against them and their leaders.

Reading out a statement in the Assembly, Home Minister G. Parameshwara said all cases registered against farmers and their leaders would be withdrawn. The police had detained 190 people and released them later. Four farmers and six policemen were injured during the protest on the busy airport road. More than 300 people missed their flights due to traffic jam following farmers’ dharna on the Airport road, he said.

He denied the Opposition’s allegation of lathi-charge against farmers.

In his reply, Chief Minister Siddaramaiah said the farmers had resorted to the protest, though he had convened a meeting on March 6 to discuss their issues.

Earlier, accusing the government of being “anti-farmer”, the Opposition BJP and the JD (S) condemned the alleged lathi-charge against the famers, who drove to the city from drought-prone districts seeking a permanent solution to drinking water and irrigation crisis.

The BJP demanded legal action against police officers who ordered a lathi-charge.

The Leader of the Opposition, Jagadish Shettar, demanded a judicial probe into the incident.
title: There was no lathi-charge, says Karnataka
